A novel approach is presented for the quantification of catalytic activity of acid catalysts used in homogeneous general acid catalysis, based on the acid-catalyzed reduction of substituted quinoline with Hantzsch ester as a model reaction. Proof of principle is demonstrated with five acids: trifluoromethanesulfonic acid, trifluoroacetic acid, two substituted BINOL-phosphoric acids featuring either 4‑methoxy-3,5-dimethylphenyl or phenanthryl groups in the 3,3´-positions and 1,1,3,3-tetrakis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)propane. The results are treated in terms of the Kimball-Collins theory and allow for a ranking of the acids based on their catalytic activity. This innovative approach offers a new, general tool for ranking acid catalysts by their catalytic activity, potentially transforming the evaluation process in this field. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Brønsted acid General acid catalysis Pseudo-first order reaction Kimball–Collins theory Transfer hydrogenation Data availability The main data are presented in the SI and additional data are available from the authors Introduction Development of novel Brønsted acid catalysts for different homogeneous reactions is a prominent research topic and numerous new acid catalysts are reported every year [1–9]. One would expect that this would have led to the accumulation of a large pool of data on rate constants of acid-catalytic reactions. Such data could be used for ranking the acid catalysts and for modelling, e.g. in the context of using machine learning tools for catalyst optimization [10–14]. Surprisingly, very little data on rate constants is available. First, most studies report reaction yields, not rate constants. Yield, however, depends on several experimental conditions, not all of which are related to the reaction rate, such as how long the reaction is run and how the product is separated. It is also well known that reaction yields are not well reproducible. Second, numerous different reactions are used. Third, even if different authors use the same reaction, they often use different conditions, e.g. molar fraction of the catalyst (X cat), temperature and solvent, so that direct comparison is not possible [15–19]. Depending on the reaction and solvent, the process can run via general or specific acid catalysis. In the case of specific acid catalysis, it is the protonated solvent that acts as the catalytic species [20]. This means that the properties of the catalyst, other than its Brønsted acidity, essentially do not influence the reaction rate. The most important consequence of this is that any stereoselectivity (incl enantioselectivity) of the catalyst is lost. For this reason, the general Brønsted acid catalysis – whereby the direct interaction of the catalyst-acid and the substrate enable stereoselectivity – is usually of more interest [21,22]. Because of the direct catalyst-substrate interaction in the general Brønsted acid catalysis, the catalysts behave differently in different reactions. Thus, it will not be possible to create a catalytic activity ranking of Brønsted acid catalysts that would be universal for all reactions. Nevertheless, in the case of homogeneous catalysis, it would be useful to define a "standard" model reaction, catalysed by the general Brønsted acid catalysis mechanism, together with reaction conditions that could be used for creating a quantitative catalytic activity scale of Brønsted acid catalysts. Although not universally applicable to all reactions, the relative positions of catalysts in such a scale could then be compared to their relative activities in other reactions to get useful insights. In this study, several factors, such as compound solubility and volatility issues, high data scatter and topical novelty, made it impossible to draw far-reaching conclusions. However, we propose a model reaction together with reaction conditions and an approach how this could be used for quantitative ranking of Brønsted acid catalysts. We demonstrate the approach on a set of five acid catalysts. Model reaction, catalysts, conditions and experiment design There are several requirements for the model reaction. The reaction has to run in a homogeneous medium. The same general acid catalysis mechanism should hold with different catalysts and there should be no side reactions. It is important that no strong bases should be formed in the reaction (that would consume the catalysts). When catalyzed, the reaction should run at a suitable rate at mild temperatures and the rate should be close to zero without a catalyst. It should be possible to follow the reaction using a well-established and widespread technique, such as NMR spectrometry. Transfer hydrogenation reaction with substituted quinoline [23,24] (2-phenylquinoline in this work, denoted as 2-PhQ) was chosen as the model reaction. It is a second-order [18] reaction where substituted or unsubstituted quinoline is reduced by Hantzsch ester, denoted as HE (both substances are of 1st partial order [18]) using Brønsted acid as a catalyst (Fig. 1 ). This reaction is an example of transfer hydrogenation reactions, which have been an area of interest for a long period of time [25–28]. It is typically carried out in a non-polar medium to ensure the possibility of asymmetric induction [23] and is catalyzed by the general acid catalysis mechanism [29]. This reaction meets the above requirements. The substrate and product are of similar basicity and the oxidized form of the HE (3,5-bis(ethoxycarbonyl)-2,6-dimethylpyridine) is a weaker base. There are no data for the exact compounds in the used solvents but the pK a values of typical quinolines and N-alkyl-anilines are in the range of 10.5 to 12.0 on acetonitrile. The approximate pK aH (pK a of the conjugate acid) of the oxidised form of HE can be estimated to be around 9 based on pK aH values of substituted pyridines [30]. The reaction can also be run under pseudo first-order conditions, which becomes important later. Five acidic catalysts of diverse chemical nature were employed (Table 1 ). The choice of catalysts was primarily limited by their solubility in the used solvents. Three acids have perfluoroalkyl groups in their structure and two have aromatic systems, which contribute to their solubility in low-polarity solvents [31]. Their acidities span close to 15 orders of magnitude, which is also beneficial as it enables to estimate the impact on the acidity on catalytic activity. The acidities of the catalysts are presented in Table 1 via their pK a values in 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE) because they have not been measured in the solvents used in this work and DCE is reasonably similar to the solvents used for carrying out the reactions: toluene-d8 (Tol-d8), benzene-d6 (Benz-d6) and CDCl3. Most of the acids have not been directly measured in DCE but their pK a(DCE) values can be conveniently estimated by using Eq. (1) [32] from the corresponding pK a values in acetonitrile MeCN (standard deviations of regression coefficients in parentheses). (1) p K a ( DCE ) = 1.10 ( 0.03 ) · p K a ( MeCN ) + 32.6 ( 0.4 ) Several measurement series were run with every catalyst in the used solvents under pseudo first-order conditions with different catalyst molar fractions relative to the substrate. Pseudo first-order conditions in this reaction were achievable with relatively low reagents’ concentrations ratio to one another. It was not possible to use higher ratios in Tol-d8 and Benz-d6 due to the HE solubility problems. In the interest of comparability, similar reagent ratios were used also in CDCl3. Experimental data were analysed with both first- and second order kinetic equations (see “1st and 2nd order reaction equations” in the SI) and the trends in -log(k) values turned out to be very similar (see Table S1 and Figure S1 in the SI), which led to the conclusion, that pseudo-first order model can be applied under the used conditions and will lead to valid comparisons of catalytic activity. It was recently found that phosphoric acids like P1 and P2 can exist in a monomer-dimer equilibrium and every form can have different impact on the reaction rate [18]. We did not account for this dimerization reaction in any way because at any given X cat the equilibrium is constant, provided that the other reaction parameters are the same. Every experimental data series yielded a value for the first-order rate constant k. These k values are not directly comparable because they correspond to different X cat values. Therefore, to analyse the data and to compare the catalytic activity of the catalysts, relationships between log(k) and X cat were investigated. To give an objective and minimally X cat-dependent assessment of the catalytic ability of the different catalysts and to compare them with each other, a model was sought that expresses the dependence between the rate constant and X cat. The Kimball-Collins theory [37], which applies to first-order reactions, appears to best describe this relationship. It can be formalized in a somewhat simplified way via the model expressed with Eq. (2). The model assumes that the overall rate constant k depends on the rate constants of two individual processes: diffusion of the reactants with rate constant k D and the rate of the reaction itself with rate constant k R . k D expresses the rate at which reactant molecules come close enough to each other to interact. k R expresses the average rate at which molecular transformation occurs as a result of the interaction of reactant molecules. We assume that k R can be expressed as the product of the molar fraction of the catalyst and a coefficient b, which expresses the catalytic activity of the catalyst and depends on the reaction, solvent, temperature, and catalyst but not on the molar fraction of the catalyst. k D , however, is in the case of the same reaction dependent only on the solvent used but is independent of the catalyst. Therefore, in every solvent the same k D value holds for all the catalysts. (2) k = k R k D k R + k D = b X Cat k D b X Cat + k D Experimental Reagents The substrates 2-phenylquinoline (CAS 612–96–4, Sigma-Aldrich, 99 %) and Hantzsch ester (CAS 1149–23–1, Alfa Aesar, 98 %) were used without further purification. Trifluoromethanesulfonic acid (Fluka, ≥99 %) and trifluoroacetic acid (Alfa Aesar, 99 %) of commercial origin were used as catalysts without further purification. The catalysts P1 [17] ((11bR)-2,6-di-(4‑methoxy-3,5-dimethylphenyl)-4‑hydroxy-dinaphtho[2,1-d:1′,2′-f][1,3,2]dioxaphosphepin-4-oxide), P2 [35] ((11bR)-2,6-di-9-phenanthrenyl-4‑hydroxy-dinaphtho[2,1-d:1′,2′-f][1,3,2]dioxaphosphepin-4-oxide) and C1 [36] (1,1,3,3-tetrakis-(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)propane) were the same as in previous publications. Benz-d6, Tol-d8 and CDCl3 from Deutero (≥99.5 %, fresh, therefore was not deacidified) were used as solvents. Instruments All chemicals were stored, and all solutions were prepared inside a glovebox (MBraun Unilab) filled with 99.999 % pure argon (5.0, Linde Gas). The oxygen content inside the glovebox was always under 50 ppm and water content below 1 ppm. 1H NMR measurements were performed using a Bruker AVANCE III 700 NMR spectrometer (700.1 MHz 1H) with a 5 mm BBO probe head. NMR spectra were registered using TopSpin 3.2 software with the default pulse program zg30. During the kinetic measurements, all samples inside the NMR were thermostated to a temperature of (25.0 ± 0.1) °C in the NMR magnet. However, the samples were not in the NMR magnet all the time during the measurement. The reason was that several reactions were run in parallel and samples were interchanged between the magnet and autosampler. Thus, the average temperature in the sample may have been different from 25.0 °C. We conservatively estimate that the temperature of the solutions was in the range of (25±3) °C throughout the measurement series. Every obtained spectrum was a result of 32 averaged scans (every scan was done in 18–20 min interval), a total of 32 NMR spectra was obtained to construct a kinetic curve for every reaction. Spectrum finish time was used as a time stamp for the data. Water content in the reaction mixtures after NMR measurements was occasionally measured using coulometric Karl Fischer titration and was always below 25 ppm. Experimental procedure All reaction mixtures for the kinetic measurements were prepared inside a glovebox. The solutions consisted of 2-PhQ, HE and a catalyst dissolved in a deuterated solvent. The concentrations of the HE and 2-PhQ varied minimally between different measurements to ensure the reproducibility of results. Only the concentration of the catalyst was varied. The 2-PhQ and HE concentrations in the reaction mixtures were (3.4 ± 0.2)⋅10−3 M and (9.0 ± 0.5)⋅10−3 M, respectively. There were always at least 2.55 equivalents of HE in relation to 2-PhQ. As for the acidic catalysts, the solutions were prepared considering the molecular weight of the catalyst and the desired X cat. Due to very low desired concentrations, catalyst solutions always had to be diluted. The most significant limitation in preparing the solutions was the solubility of HE. In both Benz-d6 and Tol-d8, its solubility in these solvents is approximately 10−2 M. It was not practical to prepare solutions with lower concentrations because, for obtaining an acceptable signal-to-noise ratio, the initial concentration of 2-PhQ had to be higher than 10−3 M. At lower concentrations, the peaks in the NMR spectrum had too low intensity. An ultrasonic bath was used to accelerate HE dissolution in the reaction mixture (without the catalyst) in Benz-d6 and Tol-d8. The same was done for P1 and P2 catalyst solutions. Because using the ultrasonic bath was only possible outside the glovebox, preventing the increase in water in the reaction mixture was essential. For this purpose, the caps of the vials with the solutions were tightly closed and covered with a layer of Parafilm® before taking them out of the glovebox. The ultrasonic bath was used for 30 min at a temperature of 65 °C. It was experimentally confirmed that the reaction between 2-PhQ and HE is too slow to occur significantly without the catalyst and that the reactants do not decompose at this temperature (see “Example of the reaction proceeding with no catalyst” in SI). Once the substances were fully dissolved, the reaction mixture was equally divided between two borosilicate glass NMR tubes and a catalyst solution was added. The catalyst was added at the end of the preparation stage using micro syringe to minimize the time between the reaction start and the start of the kinetics measurements. Standard NMR tube cap was tightly sealed with Parafilm® before taking the tube to the NMR spectrometer. This step was necessary because the reaction lasted for several hours, and moisture can enter the tube through the cap if it is not sufficiently sealed. Data treatment methods After the experiment, both 2-PhQ and solvent NMR signals were integrated. NMR spectra of 2-PhQ and its product in all used solvents can be found in the SI. 2-PhQ integral values were divided by the solvent integral values and the ratios of their areas were used as experimental data points for constructing the kinetic curve. Time-separated NMR spectra of the reaction can be found in the SI. Utilizing signal ratios instead of the 2-PhQ signals aids in compensating for signal intensity fluctuations during measurements. This data treatment method proved challenging in Benz-d6, as the 2-PhQ NMR signals partially overlapped with the solvent NMR signal. To maintain consistency between all solvents and due to the significantly higher intensity of the solvent NMR signal compared to the 2-PhQ product NMR signal, the same data treatment method was used for Benz-d6. Potential errors were subsequently addressed through uncertainty estimation. The signal area S at time t is a function of the equilibrium concentration C of the reactant [38], which in this work is referred to as the kinetic curve. It is a function S δ = f(t), where S δ is the ratio of the areas of the reactant signal and the solvent signal at the chemical shift δ, and t is the time at a certain moment of the reaction. The signal areas were found within a certain range of chemical shifts, determined empirically. The equations for the kinetic curves of first and second order reactions are as follows: (3) S = S Q · e − k 1 t + S f (4) S = a · S Q S H · e a k 2 t − 2 S Q + S f The signal areas S represent the areas of the substituted quinoline signals at the beginning of the reaction (S Q), the same signals at the end of the reaction (S f), and the baseline areas of the HE signals at the beginning of the reaction (S H), respectively. k 1 and k 2 are the first and second order rate constants. Eqs. (3) and (4) are modified versions of the first and second order reaction kinetic equations (see “1st and 2nd order reaction equations” in SI). Eqs. (3) and (4) are used to calculate the values of the reaction rate constants k by fitting them to the data using the least squares method, i.e. finding a function that corresponds to the minimal sum of the squares of the differences between the theoretical and experimental points. Multiple parameters were varied using the least squares method to describe the curve: S Q, S f, k 1 in case of Eq. (3) and S Q, S f, S H, k 2 in case of Eq. (4). S Q and S H parametrization was limited because they had to correspond to values measured prior to the reaction start. Results The rate constants obtained with different catalysts at different mole fractions in Tol-d8, together with the model relationships according to the Kimball-Collins theory, Eq. (2), are presented in Fig. 2 . Full rate constant data for all solvents is presented in Table S1. The rate constants were measured, and the results modelled according to Eq. (2) for acids P1, P2 and C1 in all three solvents: Tol-d8, Benz-d6 and CDCl3. In addition, the TfOH and TFA were investigated in Tol-d8. Solvents other than Tol-d8 were used as structurally similar (Benz-d6) or somewhat different (CDCl3) media to figure out if the structure of used solvent is related to the result. The parameters b and k D obtained from the modelling are presented in Table 2 . From Fig. 2, it can be observed that most points agree satisfactorily with the model curve. As explained above, when introducing the Kimball-Collins theory, the b parameter of eq (2) was varied separately for every model (every acid catalyst in every solvent), but the k D parameter was the same for all acid catalysts in the same solvent and therefore altogether only 3 values of k D were found. This explains the way the individual model curves behave in Fig. 2: for every acid catalyst individually, the curve could have been fitted to the data points better if the k D value would be allowed to change individually for every acid catalyst. For liquid acids with high vapor pressure (TfOH and TFA), the scatter of data points around the curve is generally higher than for solid acids (P1, P2, and C1). In the case of TfOH the trend is still well identifiable. In the case of TFA the agreement between the data points and the model is satisfactory at best. The TfOH graph in Tol-d8 has acceptable scatter, but the experiments with TfOH in the Benz-d6 environment indicated that satisfactory reproducibility could not be achieved: the results were completely inadequate and were not included in the work. This was the reason why only the results of solid acids (P1, P2, C1) are presented in other solvents. The higher scatter is most likely due to the high uncertainty in weighing small amounts of volatile acids. There are 2 ways to obtain -log(k) values: using normalized or unnormalized NMR signal area values. The necessity for normalization comes from the fact that during data analysis, 2-PhQ NMR signal area values get divided by the solvent NMR signal area values. These values are different in different solvents and therefore, the obtained results will not correspond to the reagents’ concentration in the same way. It is also possible to assign higher weight to certain experimentally obtained rate constants than to others whilst fitting them to calculate b and k D values via model of Eq. (2). In this case, the experiments yielding smaller -log(k) values (i.e. faster reactions) were assigned higher weights. This was done on the assumption that measurement of k at higher catalyst concentration is more accurate, because possible catalyst losses, e.g. for side-reactions, such as reacting with impurities are relatively less influential. All these calculation methods enable the assessment of the uncertainty arising from the scatter of the -log(k) values around the model curve and the different assumptions of modelling. In total, the values of the catalytic activity indicators b and the diffusion rate constants k D were obtained for each solvent by fitting the data to the model of Eq. (2) using 4 data treatment variants: log(k) found from unnormalized data and using unweighted fitting to Eq. (2), -log(k) found from unnormalized data and using weighted fitting to Eq. (2), -log(k) found from normalized data and using unweighted fitting to Eq. (2), -log(k) found from normalized and using weighted fitting to Eq. (2). The values of b and k D presented in Table 2 were obtained as arithmetic means from these 4 variants. The uncertainty estimates of the parameter values were obtained in a simplified manner: the uncertainty estimate is the absolute value of the largest difference between the arithmetic mean of the respective found parameter and the obtained parameters’ value from one of the above approaches, rounded up. Table 3 presents the averages of the ratios of the b values. Their uncertainty estimates were found using the same approach. Ratios provide a better idea of how the catalytic activities of the acids relate to each other. Discussion The used approach enables directly comparing the catalytic activities of the acids in the investigated reaction, using their b values and b values’ ratios. Acid C1 has by its b value the weakest catalytic ability in the investigated reaction among the acids studied in all three solvents. The b values of acids P1 and P2 are similar to each other whilst using the same solvent. Their similar catalytic activity is expected, as they are structurally similar substances. TfOH in Tol-d8 has higher catalytic activity than TFA, whose catalytic activity is the lowest among the acids studied in Tol-d8. The catalytic activity of acids P1 and P2 is comparable to that of TfOH. Based on these data, it can be concluded that the catalytic activities of TFA and C1 in the Tol-d8 environment are lower than the catalytic activities of TfOH, P1, and P2. For P1, P2, and C1, the same conclusion can be made for all solvents except CDCl3: considering the uncertainties, it is not possible to state that the catalytic activities of P1 and C1 in the CDCl3 environment are statistically different. Comparing the obtained b values of the catalysts with their pK a values, it is not possible to find a relationship between catalytic activity and acid strength from the obtained data. This also means that there is no general relationship between catalytic activity and acidity of the solution, expressed as the unified pH ( pH abs H 2 O ) value (see [33,39] for detailed explanations on pH abs H 2 O ), as pH abs H 2 O follows the pK a as long as acid concentration is constant. There is, of course, relationship between catalytic activity and pH abs H 2 O in the case of the same acid: reaction becomes faster and pH abs H 2 O becomes lower when acid concentration increases. Table S1 in the SI reveals that the overall -log(k) values obtained in the CDCl3 environment tend to be on average higher than in other two solvents. Experimental data showed that the reaction in CDCl3 is indeed slower than in the other two solvents: on average, a significant portion of the reactant was still unreacted after 10 h, while practically all the reactant reacted after an average of 8 h in other solvents. Table 2 shows that in the case of CDCl3, the b values of the acidic catalysts P1 and P2 are significantly lower than in other solvents, which reflects this phenomenon. The -log( k D ) value is higher in the case of CDCl3, which means that the diffusion rate is lower than when using the other two solvents. This also contributes to smaller k values in CDCl3. Rate of diffusion in a solvent is linked to its viscosity. However, in this case the viscosities of the tree solvents are similar: η(Tol) = 554 µPa⋅s [40] (at 25 °C), η(Benz) = 586 µPa⋅s [41] (at 27 °C), η(CHCl3) = 542 µPa⋅s [42] (at 25 °C), so that something else, such as different solvation ability of the solvents, is responsible for the difference. Conclusions In this study, experiments were conducted on the transfer hydrogenation reaction of 2-phenylquinoline using organic Brønsted acids as catalysts to determine whether the reaction is suitable as a model reaction for comparing the catalytic abilities of Brønsted acids as catalysts. The experiments showed that the reaction proceeded as expected. The obtained results showed that the reaction rate depends on the catalyst used, the solvent, and the catalyst molar fraction. To clarify the latter dependence, the authors relied on the Kimball-Collins theory, which limited the obtained results to those derived from the first-order equation. The Kimball-Collins model enables a quantitative assessment of the catalytic abilities of different catalysts, independent of the catalyst-substrate concentration ratio. Quantitative results were obtained for 5 acidic catalysts in Tol-d8 and for 3 acidic catalysts in Benz-d6 and CDCl3. Despite the high measurement uncertainty, it was possible to identify that certain acids have higher catalytic activity than others and that the relative catalytic activities remain similar in different solvents. It was not possible to identify any relationship between catalytic activity and the strength (pK a value) of the corresponding acids. For further development of the work, a larger selection of acids and solvents should be used, and more data points should be measured to reduce uncertainty. To determine the universality of the approach demonstrated in this work, further experiments with the same acidic catalysts but different model reaction are needed. coredata.dc:description: A novel approach is presented for the quantification of catalytic activity of acid catalysts used in homogeneous general acid catalysis, based on the acid-catalyzed reduction of substituted quinoline with Hantzsch ester as a model reaction. Proof of principle is demonstrated with five acids: trifluoromethanesulfonic acid, trifluoroacetic acid, two substituted BINOL-phosphoric acids featuring either 4‑methoxy-3,5-dimethylphenyl or phenanthryl groups in the 3,3´-positions and 1,1,3,3-tetrakis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)propane. The results are treated in terms of the Kimball-Collins theory and allow for a ranking of the acids based on their catalytic activity. This innovative approach offers a new, general tool for ranking acid catalysts by their catalytic activity, potentially transforming the evaluation process in this field.
